JUDGES: Egbert Myjer;Ineta Ziemele;Ján Šikuta;Josep Casadevall;Kristina Pardalos;Luis López Guerra;Mihai Poalelungi
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in PERSON , GPE .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the applicant applied for early retirement , after having worked for ORG . His DATE pension amounted to MONEY . The legislation in force at the time , namely PERSON no . CARDINAL on State military pensions , allowed early retirees from the armed forces to apply for jobs in both the public and private sector , the status of retiree and that of employee being compatible .

On DATE the applicant was appointed by the mayor of ORG , a small town in GPE , to work as a head of department within ORG . His DATE salary amounted to MONEY , to which an additional allowance of PERCENT of his basic salary was paid on a DATE basis .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE , following the entry into force of Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on rationalisation of public expenditure , which introduced certain conditions for the concurrent receipt of a pension and of a ORG - paid salary ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , the applicant was notified by his employer that in view of the fact that his pension exceeded the national average gross salary of CARDINAL lei ( see also paragraph CARDINAL below ) , he was obliged to choose within DATE between having his pension suspended for the duration of his employment contract , or having the employment contract terminated .

The applicant refused to make such a choice , allegedly considering that the legal provisions preventing him from receiving concomitantly a pension and a salary were unconstitutional and in breach of NORP legislation and of the human rights treaties .
Consequently , on DATE the mayor issued a decision confirming that from DATE the applicant ’s appointment as head of department was revoked , pursuant to LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant contested the mayor ’s decision before ORG . He asked to be reinstated in his previous post and to be paid the corresponding salaries , retroactively , for the period since DATE . The applicant mainly claimed that the provisions of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL were in breach of LAW and of LAW , as they infringed his right to work and to have his possessions , namely DATE income , protected .

CARDINAL . ORG dismissed the applicant ’s action on DATE . It noted that the applicant did receive both a pension and a salary from a public institution , even though his pension exceeded the level of the national average gross salary , which was CARDINAL lei for DATE . Therefore , it held that section CARDINAL of Law no CARDINAL/CARDINAL , which had already been declared constitutional by ORG , was relevant to his situation and justified the termination of his employment in a public institution .

Concerning the alleged breach of the applicant ’s right to work , the court held that he was still entitled to receive a salary if he were employed in the private sector ; furthermore , the contested measure was not discriminatory , since it applied equally to all persons that were in the same situation as that described in the legal instrument .

CARDINAL . The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law against this judgment , invoking also a breach of his rights under LAW No . CARDINAL to LAW CARDINAL of the Convention , Article CARDINAL of Protocol No . CARDINAL to LAW CARDINAL paragraph CARDINAL of LAW .

CARDINAL . His appeal was dismissed on DATE by ORG . The court reiterated that the provisions of the disputed law had been declared constitutional by ORG , its decision being final and binding . In so far as the applicant ’s criticism of the law coincided with the arguments already assessed and taken into consideration by ORG in its reasoning , the court was bound to follow ORG approach . It followed that the mayor ’s decision to terminate the applicant ’s employment was lawful and in compliance with LAW .

CARDINAL . Law no CARDINAL/CARDINAL , concerning the reorganising of public authorities and institutions , rationalisation of public expenditure , provision of support for the business field and compliance with the agreements signed with ORG and ORG , came into force on DATE . Its chapter PERSON was dedicated to “ Measures regulating concurrent pension and salary entitlements , aimed at reducing public expenditure ” .

DATE Anyone entitled to receive a pension , under either the ORG pension scheme or another pension scheme , who is also entitled to receive a salary pursuant to an employment contract or act of appointment within a public institution , whether national or local ... , shall be allowed to combine the pension with the salary if the pension received is lower than the national average gross salary , as validated by LAW .
DATE The provisions of paragraph CARDINAL shall be applicable to persons who :
( a ) at the time of the entry into force of this chapter , are retired and enjoy concurrent pension and salary entitlements ( pensionari cumularzi ) ;
( b ) after the entry into force of this chapter , begin to enjoy concurrent pension and salary entitlements .

CARDINAL – Persons who are retired and fall under the provisions of section PERSON ) ( b ) and who practise a profession pursuant to an employment contract or an act of appointment shall have an obligation , within DATE following the entry into force of this chapter , to express in writing their choice between having the payment of their pension suspended while they practise that profession or having their employment / appointment terminated , in the event that the amount of their net pension exceeds the national average gross salary , as validated by LAW ...

Refusal to comply with the obligation to express a choice within the deadline set out in section CARDINAL ... shall constitute justification for the termination of employment , whether it was based on a contract or on an act of appointment .
If the choice is expressed within the time - limit set out in section CARDINAL ... , the payment of the pension shall be suspended from DATE .
Any payments received unduly shall be recovered from the retiree , in compliance with the general rules on the statute of limitations / negative prescription .

CARDINAL . The above - mentioned provisions of Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL have been subjected to the scrutiny of ORG , both before its promulgation ( pre - legislative review ) and after its entry into force ( postlegislative review ) , as follows .

CARDINAL . On DATE CARDINAL NORP MPs seised ORG of a request for pre - legislative review of constitutionality concerning sections CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL . ORG gave its decision on DATE , finding that the impugned legal texts were in compliance with LAW .

While stating from the outset that the provisions of the impugned law could not apply to persons whose mandates were provided for by LAW ( for example , high - ranking officials ) , the court mainly stated , on the issue of concurrent pension and salary entitlements , that no constitutional provision prevented the legislature from prohibiting the concurrent receipt of both pension and salary , provided that such a measure was applied in an equal manner for all citizens , and that any potential differences in treatment were proved to have a legitimate aim . At the same time , the context in which the impugned measure was taken was an exceptional one , having regard to the global crisis on a financial and economic level .

ORG further stated that the legislation allowed , as a rule , the concurrent receipt of pension and salary , if the pension was lower than a certain level ; the level taken into account was expressly prescribed by law , and was thus predictable and determinable , while at the same time reasonable . The exception to the rule of combining both incomes was justified by the exceptional economic circumstances and applied only to those who were employed or appointed in the public sector , for the purpose of rationalising public expenditure , while also securing a certain level of income DATE estimated as reasonable – for everyone . In so far as the measure applied equally to all those concerned by the legal instrument , it could not be regarded as discriminatory .

In conclusion , the court held that the legislature had full discretionary power to institute such measures as imposing a certain level of secured income , in so far as they were reasonable , proportionate and justified by a public interest .

CARDINAL . Subsequently , ORG was seised of several other complaints regarding the alleged unconstitutionality of sections CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL . In its decisions of CARDINAL and CARDINAL DATE , CARDINAL and DATE , CARDINAL DATE and DATE , ORG upheld its previous reasoning and confirmed that the law was in compliance with LAW . At the same time , the court reiterated that the measure could not be regarded as discriminatory , in so far as the employees in the public sector were not in a similar situation to those working for private employers , essentially owing to the fact that their incomes were dependent on the ORG budget .
